guide.conclusion: This project first appeared in Make: Halloween Special Edition, page 69.

flags.title: From MAKE Magazine
flags.text: This project first appeared on the pages of MAKE magazine.

guide.introduction: I've served a Meat Head at my Halloween parties for at least the last five years. It never fails to impress (and distress!) my guests.
guide.introduction_rendered:
I've served a Meat Head at my Halloween parties for at least the last five years. It never fails to impress (and distress!) my guests.

Relevant parts
  • Plastic skull
  • Jell-O
  • Pickled onions
  • Olives
  • Lettuce
Tools
  • Knife
  • Pan
  • Plastic wrap
  • Plate

lines.text: Wash it well, and make sure it’s clean enough to eat off of. Because that’s what you’re going to do.
lines.text_raw: Wash it well, and make sure it’s clean enough to eat off of. Because that’s what you’re going to do.

lines.text: Congeal yourself some Jell-O in a big flat pan. Red flavors are best (I used green one year when Meat Head was a Vulcan).
lines.text_raw: Congeal yourself some Jell-O in a big flat pan. Red flavors are best (I used green one year when Meat Head was a Vulcan).

lines.text: Use only half the water the recipe calls for, to make the Jell-O nice and rubbery.
lines.text_raw: Use only half the water the recipe calls for, to make the Jell-O nice and rubbery.

lines.text: Cut the Jell-O into strips and patches about ¼" thick, and layer it across the skull. This makes an interesting bottom layer for your guests to discover.
lines.text_raw: Cut the Jell-O into strips and patches about ¼" thick, and layer it across the skull. This makes an interesting bottom layer for your guests to discover.

lines.text: Next, take strips of cold cuts and layer them across the skull. (A pound-and-a-half is plenty.) You don’t want to use too much, or else your guests won’t eat their way down to the Jell-O surprise that’s waiting for them!
lines.text_raw: Next, take strips of cold cuts and layer them across the skull. (A pound-and-a-half is plenty.) You don’t want to use too much, or else your guests won’t eat their way down to the Jell-O surprise that’s waiting for them!

lines.text: It's a ham Meat Head, which gives a Freddy Krueger complexion. It's used corned beef, for the look of someone with their outer layer of skin peeled off, and turkey, for a nice zombie appearance. You’ll need to use strategically placed toothpicks to prevent the cold cuts from sliding off the head.
lines.text_raw: It's a ham Meat Head, which gives a Freddy Krueger complexion. It's used corned beef, for the look of someone with their outer layer of skin peeled off, and turkey, for a nice zombie appearance. You’ll need to use strategically placed toothpicks to prevent the cold cuts from sliding off the head.

lines.text: Add the eyes. I recommend pickled onions, for their pleasing translucency. The yolks of boiled eggs give a jaundiced look, with pupils made from sliced olives.
lines.text_raw: Add the eyes. I recommend pickled onions, for their pleasing translucency. The yolks of boiled eggs give a jaundiced look, with pupils made from sliced olives.

lines.text: Cover the whole assembly with plastic wrap, and store in the fridge until party time. (Be sure to warn housemates.)
lines.text_raw: Cover the whole assembly with plastic wrap, and store in the fridge until party time. (Be sure to warn housemates.)

lines.text: it’s time for the magnificent midnight buffet! Remember to garnish Meat Head. He looks ever so much better served on a bed of green leaf lettuce, don’t you think?
lines.text_raw: it’s time for the magnificent midnight buffet! Remember to garnish Meat Head. He looks ever so much better served on a bed of green leaf lettuce, don’t you think?

guide.summary: Craving some cranium? You've come to the right place.
guide.title: Meat Head
